messageBody:
Hi!!!

I'm rather new in the junit world, and
there is a question that has been running through my head for some time...

Are the configuration files of frameworks we use everyday needed to be tested?

I think they are. Quite a lot of bugs come from typos, or little
mistakes in xml files.
And using a DTD doesn't completely address the problem.
For example we have Hibernate hbm mapping files.
There's a lot of reflection configuration there, and no dtd will check that.

My concrete problem is that I want to test hibernate configuration.
I have two ideas on how to do this:

1. Use dbunit, hsqldb to make some basic operations over my
persistent classes. This way I'm pretty sure they are correctly mapped.
2. I somehow manage to test the configuration files.

I've already tried the first one, but it seems to me like a lot of
work, and It feels like testing two things: hibernate and my config
files when I only want to test the files.

Therefore, I want to follow the second approach because it looks more
accuratet to me; but I don't know how, or if there is something out
there that does that job for me (It looks like a common problem).

Maybe I'm wrong, and the common thing is not testing the config files,
because integration tests will do that for me. Is this true?!

Well, any link or google searchphrase will be appreciated.. :D

Thanks in advance,
Mariano Cortesi
